subject: RE: [junit] Testing super-class contracts (test case reuse)
msgSnippet: ... The names of the classes make that obvious. Returning to my example, if I want to see how Bag works, I look for anything that has BagTest in the name.
messageBody:
>So said Tharp, Joshua L, SOLGV on 2003-06-30 --------------------
>[JBR]
>....Agreed, and so using nested classes for related fixtures is not a bad
>idea at all. I just don't think that it's necessarily any clearer: it's
>just all in one file rather than in three.
>
>
>Your points are good, but they seem to boil down to having several
>different classes with good names and all will be right with the world.
>While that may be true, the problem I have is more at the package scope.
>When looking at a directory, how do you know where to start looking?

The names of the classes make that obvious. Returning to my example, if I want to see how Bag works, I look for anything that has "BagTest" in the name. The fact that there may be four classes matches those criteria shouldn't be a big problem.

>The
>reason I like the inner classes is that you can set up a test suite of
>sorts in an obviously named class. With those inner classes, you can
>still have several test files that support that main one, but if you are
>entering a directory to investigate someone else's testing strategy,
>then having a well-defined starting point is a great help. Don't get me
>wrong, you can still use several different files, so long as they are
>referenced from within an obviously named one. Using your Bag examples,
>I would say that the BagTest should refer to the other two, and possibly
>a third that actually has the run-of-the-mill type tests. That way, when
>entering a directory with tests for 20 or more classes (look at
>java.util for example), I could find BagTest.java quickly and from there
>discover the other test classes that are directly applicable.

Some projects have used a different approach. They manage test suites manually. What you have called "BagTest" would be "BagSuite" for them, and in BagSuite you would find a hand-built test suite that refers to all the classes that contain tests for a Bag. BagSuite would refer to EmptyBagTest, HelloTwiceBagTest and OneItemBagTest, for example. This way you know immediately to look at BagSuite to find all the bag tests.

When you open it, though, BagSuite does nothing more than say "see EmptyBagTest, HelloTwiceBagTest and OneItemBagTest for details." I claim that seeing the three Java source files all named *BagTest.java does the same work without the extra source file.

As for a well-defined starting point, the set of test files *BagTest.java *is* a well-defined, obviously-named starting point. It is perhaps slightly less obvious than opening "BagTest.java", but not so much that it poses a problem. If someone wants to write "BagTest.java", then that's cool with me, but I wouldn't do it.

>Granted, this is all beginning to sound like the student teaching the
>teacher, but while I lack some JUnit experience, the software
>engineering experience is there. One of the hardest things about
>approaching a body of source code (production or test) is figuring out
>where to start. To that end, it seems having a single, well-named
>starting point makes great strides.

It does. Another technique is talking to people: a close-knit team will agree to standards and uphold them, obviating the need for documentation masquerading as code. Another technique is a drawing on the wall, or a list on the corkboard.

I have a general aversion to code that does nothing more than document something. That's why we have documentation. Code should be self-documenting, but it should also do something useful at runtime.

And keep in mind: we'll all teachers and students here.

Take care.

[Conclusion: I don't think what you're doing is bad; but I wouldn't do it myself, because I would solve the same problem a different way.]
